The Meat President.-The reason why the jack
son men throughout the Union, in print, and in con-
versation, assert positively and unblushingy that
their mild and darling candidate, will have an over
whelmng majority at the next Presidential Election,
isto misead the wavering portion ofthe public 1t
is well known, that many thousand voters on every
great political question, suffer themselves to be gui-
ded by what they term, the strongest side. Hence
it is, that the bold and daring friends ofgenera jack
son, proclaim his success in anticipation. The re-
suit will be otherwise, have no hesitation in be-


eving, and they dread it. The late elections in
Maryland, Delaware and Pennsylvania strong
indications of the increased and increasing strength
of the Administration. Good order and regular
government, must and will prevail, over anarchy,
despotism and turbulence. Let the people look dis
passionately at the subject +.

rosnectfL manner in which the President was re-
ceved by the city authorities of Philadelphia and BY
all the most respectable citizens generally, must have
been gratifying to the distinguished individual as II
was honorable to the city.

in mind, the ANrI-D DEsporIc Convention Of Virgil

we have no doubt !; and we have too much conf
dence in his good sense and in his 1--we OF country,
to harbor fear that false decacy will be allowed
IN depriye us of the invaluable influence which would
result from his presence. ~

Mr. Eaton never expected that Mr.. Clay would al
lude to $50 small busness' as bis 1900 dollar
loan to Stephen Simpson, Editor of the Columbian
Observer. This transaction, to Mr.. Eaton's mind, !,
was very Innocent and unoffendng one. At the
request of the Editors Of that paper, Mr.. Senator
Eaton, the colleague, the friend, and bographer Of
General Jackson" according to his own acknow.
ledgment, " did lend a sam of money" 1t was ac-
tually Mr.. Eaton's own money ~ 1t was indeed
for he says Mr.. E. thinks it might be wrong
to lend Editors money " as stipend to induce to a
course not sanctioned by their preference or udg-
ment." But just look here-Mr. Eaton discovered
that Mr.. Simpson, for eighteen months or more
had habonred IN support Of Aadreao Jachson:" and
that, dye see, materially altered the case.


Simpson had really taken his stand-and there
fore MIR. Eaton thought he could lend him money
with propriety, without the charge Of :. improving
the press" This press, every one knows who saw
the papers issued from it, was Of the most abus-
i've and dsgracefu that appeared in this coun,
try 1t could not be tolerated by many Of the Jack.
sonians themselves But this is rather g small
business'-Mr. Eaton has right to lend his " own
money" ashe peases-and is not to be censured for
aiding man, at his own request, who had ''labor-
ed more than eighteen months to- support Andrew
Jackson s'There's no mistake about that.''
so SMALL A BUSINESS /"

The steam boat North America performed trip
last week between Albany and New York, in 10
hours and 40 minutes.

bo entered on the duties of his office as Governor

The Roston Commercial Gazette mentions, that a
lot of land at the head of Long Wharf Portland,
vacated by the late fire, has been purchased BY a
numberof gentlemen who propose to erect upon 1t
Mariners Church. Severals thousand dollars have
already been subscribed by the citizens, towards
the audabc undertaking.
Messrs. Wait and Son. Of Boston. have Just pub
lished an English translation Of the personal Nara
five of the first voyage Of Columbus to Amer'ca.-
rhis narrative has been recently for the first time
published il Spain, by Mr.. Navarretta, from the
original manuscript lately discovered. A full and
interesting notice of the work was given IN late
number Of the North American Review.

pha, Montgomery, Berks, Lancaster, Dauphin,

Of the Opposition has been much overrated, as the

The National Journal, speaking of the results of
the late elections in Maryland, Delaware, SC. &c.
remarks


They show two important facts. In the first place
they satisfactorily prove that the charges made
against the Administration have not produced that
effect on the public mind which those who made
them, relying on the imaginary influence of their
own talents and perseverance, had hoped and anti
cipated. They prove that the boasted evidence
talked about by Mr.. M'Duthe, as being as conclu-
sive on the charge Of corruption, is required in
Court Of justice to insure capital conviction has
produced precisely an opposite verdict before the
tribunal of public opinion and led to acquttal in,
stead of condemnation. In the second place, they
have exposed to the people the tallacies which the
Opposition editors in the practice of circulating
as to the real course ofpublic opinion and the in,
correctness of the calculations with which they fa
vor their readers. No doubt they had persuaded
those who believe in their predictions, that in all the
three instances which we haye given, the result:
would be as splendid in favor of General Jackson
as they have proved to be in favor of Mr.. Adams
and his Administration. Will those who have beer
thus deludcd, be persuaded again to pm their fait
), on the sleeves of such prophets !?
Part of PENNSYLVANIA.

Aourishing. About one hundred vessels, and 1000
seamen, it is thought are employed in the whale
fisheries, and the town contains G, 900 Inhabitants.
| Emigration TO the British Colonies The Brig
James arrived at Halifax early in September. with
1870 passengers, and was quarantned on account OF
the Typhus Fever which prevailed on board.$


Seven Kindred emigrants were to embark IN the
end of July at Tobermora, destined for the island
of Cape Breton, 600 emigrated from the same place


last year, and it is stated that 1000 more individuals
have determined to follow their friends and relations
to their transatlantic settlement next year.
A number of poor Irish emigrants have been
abandoned at Quebeck, by the master Of the vessel
| who brought them over, and promised to provide
transportation to Upper Canads. .lf
Camden, S. C. Sept. 22.--On "Wednesday last,
an Alligator, If unusual large size, was discovered
by negro man, crossing the main road, short DIS"
tance below the Bridge over Pine tree creek. tie
was pursued, the negro having collected number
of others, and discovered in small pond, formed IN
the bend Of the creek-Ts course to the main creek
being thus cut off, and the shaownessof the water
preventing bis concealing himself, rope was'pro-
cured, and as he lay near the shore, moose pass
ed over his head. He did not attempt to escape un-
til he felt the rope around his neck, when his exer
tions became violent. When partially exhausted by
his efforts, and stranged by the rope, they succee-
ded in cutting his throat He was brought to this
place. and measured ten and half feet in length,
and weighed 546 pounds.


| F1sHERIEs.--The NJ Y. Daily Advertiser gives
the following brief statement df the American fshe-
ries in the gulf of St. Lawrence trade which the
English endeayoring to secure to themselves.
A plan to accomplish this object has been recently
publishedin London.


j About 1000 sail Of American shipping, owned and
| al hv Ano llu OyQh On
those shores, in catching Goldfish. They vessels
of from 100 to $50 tons and employ about 10000
men. They prefer this fishing ground to the Banks
of Newfoundland, which proves that it is better.
They pass through the Gut of Canso, along the
north shore of Prince Edwards Islands by the coasts


of the Bay Cha!eur, up the straits of Besle, and


along the Labrador coasts rather northward from
these straits Not being permitted to land on the


shore, they take their fish home to dry, distance


of 1000 or 1900 miles, and make two voyages in a


year. The crew are sharers in the profits, and as


IL business pursued, it is justly concluded that it


must be profitable.

MARYLAND, Delaware and Pennsylvania are strong
indications of the increased and increasing strength
of the Administration. Good order and regular
government, must and will prevail, over anarchy,

From the Baltimore .qmerican.


WHEAT TRADE OF THE CONTINENT WITH ENGLAND.


From the appendix to the Report of the Lords
Committee in the British Parliament, on the price
of Foreign Grain, are taken the following particu-
lars respecting the importation of Wheat into Eng
land. Russian wheat being smaller in the berry
than any other Sort very coarse and brown, very
hardly dressed, and with much dirt in it, can seldom
be used in England for any other purpose than the
manufacture ofthe coarsest biscuit bread. At Arch
angel there are seldom any stocks of corn ofany i'm
portance and the season of receiving supplies from
the interior being limited to the few weeks when the
rivers are swollen by the melting OF the SHOWS, and
the distances being immense, the expense OF carriage
would, at very low prices, absorb nearly half the
value. AT ST. Petersburgh the consumption takes
off the greatest portion ofthe supplies and at Riga
the inferior quality Of the wheat checks its exporto
Great Britain. Prussia produces much wheat; but
though it, with other grain, forms principal object
of trade there the prices for the last few years have
not afforded sufficient inducement to the growers
and the supplies have much decreased Here, also,
the peri a of supply is only while the rivers are
swollen. Though Dantzic is celebrated for the
quality of its wheat the prices have OF late been
so ruinously low that with the cost OF transporta-
ton, they have greatly diminished its culture. The
Danish wheat is coarse and damp. The Hanse
Tozuns have many corn merchants, and capacious
granaries. Hamburg receives large supplies, and
from great distance, by river navigation and
from the great general business between and Great
Britain, there is constant trade in corn. Any de-
tciency in England causes supplies to be ordered
thence before any port except Rotterdam. Hdno-
yer and Ernbden afford indifferent wheats. In the


Netherlands there is great internal corn trade ;
but the wheats from Amsterdam, Rotterdam and
| Antwerp are usually dear, and generally too high
priced. in comparison with the English markets, to


be sent to the latter The trade in of all sorts


between England and France, is very trihing, the


population of the latter being about equal to con


sumo its produce. The excessive charges, the high


port Dues and the tardness and want OF method IN


executing orders-7together with the frequent inter


vcntion of Jours do Fetes," altogether greatly


impede the corn trade


Improuing the breed of Caue.-Our attention has
been drawn to this subject, by gentleman to whose


lteraty zeal and intelligence, this State is mucf
Indebted The importance of improving the breee


of cattle and domestic animals, is made abundantly


manifest from the fact that lean stock cattle, TO the
, value of SSOO,OOO, are yearly brought from Tho


interior of New York, and sold in this State, at al
average advance of one-hird more price, than cat


tie of similar description from the interior OF ou


own State. The cattle from New York are OF bet


ter breed than ours They feed easier and grow
! larger; and AS before stated, are considered wortl
one-third more.


: Every body knows there is little or no difference
, in the trouble and expense Of raising one colt NOR
7 than another vet one of particular make an
+ breed at given age, will be worth ten times a
\ much as the other. One horse will travel wit
5 double the speed, and perform twice the labour
IT another. and with more ease to himself. So wit
It horned cattle. One COW will give four times a
It much milk as another, and not cost a cent more
, keep her. Also with pigs. Put two pigs OF dl
L ferent breeds into the pen, and with the sam
Z, food, at a given time one pig will be found twic
d the weiqht of the other. All this shows the in
d mense importance it is to farmers to procure tn


best stock. TO promote this beneficial purpose.
r. the aim of the Agricultural Societies, and the d.
le sign of their exhibitions and cattle shows.

Experiments have shown that gunpowder COULD
be exploded by the stroke of iron upon iron; iron
upon copper; copper upon copper; iron upon marble
and by using the balistc pendulum, by lead upon
lead and with suitable precautions even by lead
upon acood. The experiments most clearly show,
that, in all the manipulatons Of powder manufac-
tory, all violent shocks and percussions should be-
carefully avoided, since they may occasion the dis
engagement of sufficient heat to produce ths nfan-
nation of powder.

In ripened Judgment, in virtue, in patriotism, and
in mind, the ANrI-D DEsporIc Convention Of Virgil
MIA, will transcend any similar assembly since JEFF
ferson, Madison, Menroe, Henry, Lee, Mason,
and others, acted together. 1t is now distinctly
known that the venerable MADISON is the author
of the five able essays under the sgature of -
FARMER" in the last of which the convention, was
nroposed Mr.. Madison is therefore the author of
the convention, and it is not chnerical to expect
that he will preside over its deliberations. That
Orange will invite him to be one OF her delegates,
we have no doubt !; and we have too much conf
dence in his good sense and in his 1--we OF country,
to harbor fear that false decacy will be allowed
IN depriye us of the invaluable influence which would
result from his presence. ~

full articles.headline: so SMALL A BUSINESS /"
full articles.article:
Mr. Eaton never expected that Mr.. Clay would al
lude to $50 small busness' as bis 1900 dollar
loan to Stephen Simpson, Editor of the Columbian
Observer. This transaction, to Mr.. Eaton's mind, !,
was very Innocent and unoffendng one. At the
request of the Editors Of that paper, Mr.. Senator
Eaton, the colleague, the friend, and bographer Of
General Jackson" according to his own acknow.
ledgment, " did lend a sam of money" 1t was ac-
tually Mr.. Eaton's own money ~ 1t was indeed
for he says Mr.. E. thinks it might be wrong
to lend Editors money " as stipend to induce to a
course not sanctioned by their preference or udg-
ment." But just look here-Mr. Eaton discovered
that Mr.. Simpson, for eighteen months or more
had habonred IN support Of Aadreao Jachson:" and
that, dye see, materially altered the case.


Simpson had really taken his stand-and there
fore MIR. Eaton thought he could lend him money
with propriety, without the charge Of :. improving
the press" This press, every one knows who saw
the papers issued from it, was Of the most abus-
i've and dsgracefu that appeared in this coun,
try 1t could not be tolerated by many Of the Jack.
sonians themselves But this is rather g small
business'-Mr. Eaton has right to lend his " own
money" ashe peases-and is not to be censured for
aiding man, at his own request, who had ''labor-
ed more than eighteen months to- support Andrew
Jackson s'There's no mistake about that.''

The Roston Commercial Gazette mentions, that a
lot of land at the head of Long Wharf Portland,
vacated by the late fire, has been purchased BY a
numberof gentlemen who propose to erect upon 1t
Mariners Church. Severals thousand dollars have
already been subscribed by the citizens, towards
the audabc undertaking.
Messrs. Wait and Son. Of Boston. have Just pub
lished an English translation Of the personal Nara
five of the first voyage Of Columbus to Amer'ca.-
rhis narrative has been recently for the first time
published il Spain, by Mr.. Navarretta, from the
original manuscript lately discovered. A full and
interesting notice of the work was given IN late
number Of the North American Review.

full articles.article:
From Poulson's Daily Advertiser it appears that
pha, Montgomery, Berks, Lancaster, Dauphin,
Mfln, Schuyikill, Franklin Chester, Delaware,
and Bucks in which Gen. Jackson, in l824,ha
majority Of 1865, he has now onl' 2o1-
king gain in favor of the Administ; ton + 9,s4i.


In some of these counties, the A4.n.. ration
candidates have succeeded and in all, the stren, III
Of the Opposition has been much overrated, as the
late elections testify.


The National Journal, speaking of the results of
the late elections in Maryland, Delaware, SC. &c.
remarks


They show two important facts. In the first place
they satisfactorily prove that the charges made
against the Administration have not produced that
effect on the public mind which those who made
them, relying on the imaginary influence of their
own talents and perseverance, had hoped and anti
cipated. They prove that the boasted evidence
talked about by Mr.. M'Duthe, as being as conclu-
sive on the charge Of corruption, is required in
Court Of justice to insure capital conviction has
produced precisely an opposite verdict before the
tribunal of public opinion and led to acquttal in,
stead of condemnation. In the second place, they
have exposed to the people the tallacies which the
Opposition editors in the practice of circulating
as to the real course ofpublic opinion and the in,
correctness of the calculations with which they fa
vor their readers. No doubt they had persuaded
those who believe in their predictions, that in all the
three instances which we haye given, the result:
would be as splendid in favor of General Jackson
as they have proved to be in favor of Mr.. Adams
and his Administration. Will those who have beer
thus deludcd, be persuaded again to pm their fait
), on the sleeves of such prophets !?

Aourishing. About one hundred vessels, and 1000
seamen, it is thought are employed in the whale
fisheries, and the town contains G, 900 Inhabitants.
| Emigration TO the British Colonies The Brig
James arrived at Halifax early in September. with
1870 passengers, and was quarantned on account OF
the Typhus Fever which prevailed on board.$


Seven Kindred emigrants were to embark IN the
end of July at Tobermora, destined for the island
of Cape Breton, 600 emigrated from the same place


last year, and it is stated that 1000 more individuals
have determined to follow their friends and relations
to their transatlantic settlement next year.
A number of poor Irish emigrants have been
abandoned at Quebeck, by the master Of the vessel
| who brought them over, and promised to provide
transportation to Upper Canads. .lf
Camden, S. C. Sept. 22.--On "Wednesday last,
an Alligator, If unusual large size, was discovered
by negro man, crossing the main road, short DIS"
tance below the Bridge over Pine tree creek. tie
was pursued, the negro having collected number
of others, and discovered in small pond, formed IN
the bend Of the creek-Ts course to the main creek
being thus cut off, and the shaownessof the water
preventing bis concealing himself, rope was'pro-
cured, and as he lay near the shore, moose pass
ed over his head. He did not attempt to escape un-
til he felt the rope around his neck, when his exer
tions became violent. When partially exhausted by
his efforts, and stranged by the rope, they succee-
ded in cutting his throat He was brought to this
place. and measured ten and half feet in length,
and weighed 546 pounds.


| F1sHERIEs.--The NJ Y. Daily Advertiser gives
the following brief statement df the American fshe-
ries in the gulf of St. Lawrence trade which the
English endeayoring to secure to themselves.
A plan to accomplish this object has been recently
publishedin London.


j About 1000 sail Of American shipping, owned and
| al hv Ano llu OyQh On
those shores, in catching Goldfish. They vessels
of from 100 to $50 tons and employ about 10000
men. They prefer this fishing ground to the Banks
of Newfoundland, which proves that it is better.
They pass through the Gut of Canso, along the
north shore of Prince Edwards Islands by the coasts


of the Bay Cha!eur, up the straits of Besle, and


along the Labrador coasts rather northward from
these straits Not being permitted to land on the


shore, they take their fish home to dry, distance


of 1000 or 1900 miles, and make two voyages in a


year. The crew are sharers in the profits, and as


IL business pursued, it is justly concluded that it


must be profitable.

MARYLAND, Delaware and Pennsylvania are strong
indications of the increased and increasing strength
of the Administration. Good order and regular
government, must and will prevail, over anarchy,
despotsm and turbulence. Let the people look dis
passionately at the subject. 7.


From the Baltimore .qmerican.


WHEAT TRADE OF THE CONTINENT WITH ENGLAND.


From the appendix to the Report of the Lords
Committee in the British Parliament, on the price
of Foreign Grain, are taken the following particu-
lars respecting the importation of Wheat into Eng
land. Russian wheat being smaller in the berry
than any other Sort very coarse and brown, very
hardly dressed, and with much dirt in it, can seldom
be used in England for any other purpose than the
manufacture ofthe coarsest biscuit bread. At Arch
angel there are seldom any stocks of corn ofany i'm
portance and the season of receiving supplies from
the interior being limited to the few weeks when the
rivers are swollen by the melting OF the SHOWS, and
the distances being immense, the expense OF carriage
would, at very low prices, absorb nearly half the
value. AT ST. Petersburgh the consumption takes
off the greatest portion ofthe supplies and at Riga
the inferior quality Of the wheat checks its exporto
Great Britain. Prussia produces much wheat; but
though it, with other grain, forms principal object
of trade there the prices for the last few years have
not afforded sufficient inducement to the growers
and the supplies have much decreased Here, also,
the peri a of supply is only while the rivers are
swollen. Though Dantzic is celebrated for the
quality of its wheat the prices have OF late been
so ruinously low that with the cost OF transporta-
ton, they have greatly diminished its culture. The
Danish wheat is coarse and damp. The Hanse
Tozuns have many corn merchants, and capacious
granaries. Hamburg receives large supplies, and
from great distance, by river navigation and
from the great general business between and Great
Britain, there is constant trade in corn. Any de-
tciency in England causes supplies to be ordered
thence before any port except Rotterdam. Hdno-
yer and Ernbden afford indifferent wheats. In the


Netherlands there is great internal corn trade ;
but the wheats from Amsterdam, Rotterdam and
| Antwerp are usually dear, and generally too high
priced. in comparison with the English markets, to


be sent to the latter The trade in of all sorts


between England and France, is very trihing, the


population of the latter being about equal to con


sumo its produce. The excessive charges, the high


port Dues and the tardness and want OF method IN


executing orders-7together with the frequent inter


vcntion of Jours do Fetes," altogether greatly


impede the corn trade


Improuing the breed of Caue.-Our attention has
been drawn to this subject, by gentleman to whose


lteraty zeal and intelligence, this State is mucf
Indebted The importance of improving the breee


of cattle and domestic animals, is made abundantly


manifest from the fact that lean stock cattle, TO the
, value of SSOO,OOO, are yearly brought from Tho


interior of New York, and sold in this State, at al
average advance of one-hird more price, than cat


tie of similar description from the interior OF ou


own State. The cattle from New York are OF bet


ter breed than ours They feed easier and grow
! larger; and AS before stated, are considered wortl
one-third more.


: Every body knows there is little or no difference
, in the trouble and expense Of raising one colt NOR
7 than another vet one of particular make an
+ breed at given age, will be worth ten times a
\ much as the other. One horse will travel wit
5 double the speed, and perform twice the labour
IT another. and with more ease to himself. So wit
It horned cattle. One COW will give four times a
It much milk as another, and not cost a cent more
, keep her. Also with pigs. Put two pigs OF dl
L ferent breeds into the pen, and with the sam
Z, food, at a given time one pig will be found twic
d the weiqht of the other. All this shows the in
d mense importance it is to farmers to procure tn


best stock. TO promote this beneficial purpose.
r. the aim of the Agricultural Societies, and the d.
le sign of their exhibitions and cattle shows.
